content: How can I help you today?

I'm here because my wife insisted I talk to someone. Things have been tough at home. My son’s behavior is out of control, and it’s causing a lot of stress between me and my wife. I’m not sure where to even start.

Thank you for sharing what's been going on. It sounds like things feel overwhelming right now, with both your son’s behavior and the tension it’s creating between you and your wife. That sounds like a heavy load to carry. What do you think your wife hoped this conversation might help with?

I think she wants me to figure out how to deal with everything—my stress, our son, and the strain on our marriage. She’s been really frustrated because we can’t seem to agree on how to help our son, and I just feel stuck. Honestly, I’m not even sure talking will fix anything.

It’s understandable to feel stuck when so much is happening at once. It sounds like there’s a lot weighing on you—your own stress, your son’s behavior, and how all of this is impacting your relationship with your wife. Even if it feels uncertain right now, talking might be an opportunity to explore what’s most important to you and figure out small steps forward. What do you think is the main thing you'd like to understand or address today?

Honestly? I feel like the main thing is figuring out what to do about my son. He's at the center of everything—it's his behavior that's creating all this stress. I just want to help him, but I don't know how. And until we figure that out, it feels like everything else, including my marriage, is falling apart.

It sounds like you're really focused on wanting to help your son and feeling uncertain about how to do it. That must be an exhausting and frustrating place to be, especially when it’s affecting so many areas of your life, including your relationship with your wife. At the heart of this, it seems like you care deeply about your family and want things to improve. What do you think has made it hard for you and your wife to agree on how to help your son?

I think it’s just that we see things so differently. She wants to handle things one way—I guess she’s more patient—and I feel like we need to be stricter, set more boundaries. But nothing seems to work, and we just end up arguing about it. It’s like we’re both trying, but we’re on completely different pages.

It sounds like you and your wife both care for your son and want the best for him, but the differences in your approaches are causing tension. It must be difficult to feel like your efforts aren’t aligned, despite both of you trying so hard. Maybe there’s some space to explore how you can bridge that gap between your perspectives. What do you think might make it easier for the two of you to find some common ground?

I honestly don’t know. We’ve tried talking about it, but it usually just turns into an argument. I think we’re both so frustrated and tired that it’s hard to really listen to each other. Maybe if we could figure out exactly what’s going on with our son, that might help us get on the same page.

It sounds like the frustration and exhaustion are making it challenging for you both to have constructive conversations right now. You want clarity—both about what’s driving your son’s behavior and how to approach it together—which might help you feel more united as parents. That’s a thoughtful way to view the situation. What do you think helps you and your wife communicate best when things aren’t as tense?

Honestly, I can’t even remember the last time we communicated well without it turning into a fight. I guess when things were better, we could just sit and talk without blaming each other or getting defensive. But with everything going on now, it feels impossible to get to that place again.

It sounds like you really miss the way you and your wife used to communicate—being able to talk openly without tension or defensiveness. With everything feeling so overwhelming now, it makes sense that it feels hard to get back to that place. Even though it feels far away, the fact that you remember how it used to feel shows that connection is still important to you. How do you think things might look if you and your wife could get closer to working as a team again?

I think it would be a huge relief. If we were on the same page, maybe we could actually make progress with helping our son instead of just arguing about how to handle things. It would also feel less lonely... like we’re tackling this together instead of feeling like it’s me against her all the time. But I don’t even know where to start to get us there.

It sounds like being able to work with your wife as a team would ease a lot of the stress and make you feel more supported—it’s clear how much that matters to you. It must be exhausting to feel like you’re on opposing sides when you’re really both trying to do what’s best for your son. Starting can feel overwhelming, but sometimes even small steps can lead to positive change. What do you think might be one small thing you could do or say to begin shifting the dynamic with your wife toward more teamwork?

Maybe I could try to tell her I want us to work together and that I don’t want it to feel like we’re on opposite sides. I guess I could ask her how she thinks we can figure this out together. It might not fix everything, but it could show her that I want to try.

That sounds like a thoughtful and meaningful first step. Expressing that you care about working together and asking for her perspective shows that you’re ready to approach this as a team. It might not solve everything immediately, but it could open the door for better communication and shared understanding. How are you feeling about taking that step?

I think it’s worth trying. I’m nervous it might turn into another argument, but I know I have to start somewhere. I just really want things to get better—for my son, my wife, and for all of us as a family.

You’re showing a lot of courage in wanting to take that step, even with the worry that it might lead to another argument. Wanting things to improve for your son, your wife, and your family shows how much you care and how committed you are to making positive changes. Starting somewhere, even if it's uncertain, can be the beginning of moving forward. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about or explore before figuring out your next steps?
I think I am okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
